Opeida 2 3 1 Institute of Chemical Technology, Martin-Luther-Universität Halle-Wittenberg, Germany Institute of Chemical Technology Martin-Luther-Universität Halle-Wittenberg Germany 1Institute of Chemical Technology, Martin-Luther-Universität Halle-Wittenberg, Germany 2 Department of Physical Chemistry of Fossil Fuels InPOCC, National Academy of Sciences of Ukraine, Lviv; Ukraine Department of Physical Chemistry of Fossil Fuels InPOCC National Academy of Sciences of Ukraine Lviv Ukraine 2Department of Physical Chemistry of Fossil Fuels InPOCC, National Academy of Sciences of Ukraine, Lviv; Ukraine 3 Vasyl’ Stus Donetsk National University, Vinnytsia, Ukraine Vasyl’ Stus Donetsk National University Vinnytsia Ukraine 3Vasyl’ Stus Donetsk National University, Vinnytsia, Ukraine ⁎ Corresponding Author. The heterogeneous catalysts based on single active component such as V2O5, MnOx and CuOx and bi-components V2O5-MoO3 V2O5-WO3 and V2O5-SbOx supported onto TiO2, TiO2-SiO2 and Al2O3-SiO2 was prepared and characterized. The aerobic liquid-phase oxidation of cumene (RH) in the presence of binary catalytic system containing N-hydroxyphthalimide (NHPI) and supported V, Mn and Cu oxides has been studied. It was observed that catalytic activities of the mono metallic systems decreases in order V2O5 ≈ MnOx > CuOx, bi-metallic catalysts showed no catalytic activities. The effect of catalytic system composition comprising MnOx or VOx and NHPI, AIBN on the oxidation rate was studied. The major oxidations product was cumene hydroperoxide, whereas dimethyl phenyl carbinol and acetophenone were found as minor ones. The reactions scheme that summarizes the oxidation chemistry identifying the related role of heterogeneous initiation and homogeneous propagation and termination steps for oxidation of cumene via free-radical mechanism are presented. Graphical Abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords cumene liquid-phase oxidation catalysts transition metal oxide N-hydroxyphthalimide 1 INTRODUCTION Oxidation of organic compounds is an important process of oxy-functionalization chemistry in both applied research and industrial applications [1]. The hydroperoxides (ROOH), as primary oxidation products of hydrocarbons, are multifunctional intermediates for synthesis of various fine chemicals, e.g. alcohols, ketones, alkenes and/or epoxides. Among hydroperoxides, cumene hydroperoxide (CHP) is widely used and frequently cited [2,3]. The main method of its production is liquid-phase oxidation of cumene by molecular oxygen. However, the chemistry of O2 is dominated by the fact that the molecule in the ground state has two unpaired electrons, whereas the hydrocarbon molecules (RH) have zero spin. The restrictions for reactivity imposed by the spin state of O2 molecule can be resolved by using its interaction with transition metal (TM) ions. Therefore, various salts of transition metals were used as homogeneous catalysts of oxidation with molecular oxygen [4,5]. Important for the improvement of aerobic oxidation methods was the discovery and extensive study of a new catalyst N-hydroxyphthalimide (NHPI), which catalyzes the chain propagation stage in radical chain processes [6-10]. Particularly, NHPI is effective in the case of free-radical chain-oxidation of cumene [11-14] increasing both rate and selectivity of the hydroperoxide formation. It is worth noting that the TM ions and NHPI are involved in different stages of the oxidation process. While TM catalyst participates in the stage of radical formation, NHPI continues with the stage of their reproduction in the chain propagation step. Thus, NHPI activated with transition metal ions in the binary catalytic systems (TM + NHPI) proves to be quite effective [15-19]. The advantages of heterogeneous catalysis - the ease of its separation from the reaction medium and the unique ability to fine tune the surface properties also attracted significant attention in the development of aerobic oxidation methods [20]. Cumene is often used as a substrate for testing new heterogeneous catalysts [21-25]. The transition metal oxides (TMO) with low cost, high thermal stability and chemical composition diversity have attracted great attention recently emerging as versatile catalysts in oxidation reactions [26]. Various Co, Mn, Fe, Cu and V supported oxide catalysts were studied in catalytic oxidation of hydrocarbons [27], epoxidation of alkenes and catalytic reduction of NOx [28,29]. In many cases, binary oxides used as catalysts demonstrate better catalytic activity [30]. Therefore, the aim of this work is the investigation of the impact of TMO composition and and their physico-chemical properties on its catalytic activity as cocatalyst of binary systems [NHPI+TMO] in the liquid-phase oxidation of cumene and the role of cocatalysts in such catalytic process. In this paper, we reported on the synthesis and characterization of series of heterogeneous catalysts comprising the Mn, Cu and V oxides supported on TiO2, TiO2-SiO2 and SiO2-Al2O3 (as a commonly used industrial support materials), their catalytic effect on the rates of liquid-phase cumene oxidation with molecular oxygen in the presence of NHPI. 2 EXPERIMENTAL 2.1 Materials All chemicals including cumene (99.9 % TCI Deutschland GmbH); acetonitrile (99.9 % Sigma-Aldrich; N-hydroxyphthalamide (NHPI) (98 % Fluka; azobisisobutyronitrile (AIBN) (98 %, Sigma-Aldrich) were commercial products. which were used as received without purification. 2.2 Catalysts preparation The catalysts containing Cu- and Mn-oxide supported on TiO2 modified with silica (SiO2 content 4.4 wt.%, ABET =160 m2 g−1 Hombikat 8602, Sachtleben Ltd) and γ-Al2O3 SiO2 (SiO2 content 20 wt.%, ABET = 250 m2 g−1, CRI Ltd, Leuna) were prepared by wet-ness impregnation of support materials with aqueous solution of manganese or copper nitrate respectively. The mixture was heated to 70°C under stirring. A measured quantity of metal nitrate was added, and the water was evaporated. The obtained paste further dried at 100°C for 13 h and calcined in air at 400°C for 5 h. V2O5/TiO2-WO3 catalysts, containing 0.2 or 2.2 wt.-% of V und 6.0% of WO3 are industrial TiO2-WO3 samples and were provided by Ebinger Katalysorservice Ltd. Three binary oxide catalysts such as V2O5-TiO2 (6 wt. % V), V2O5-MoO3/TiO2 (4.5% V and 9.2 wt. % Mo) and V2O5-SbO2/TiO2 (4 wt.% V and 9.7 wt.% Sb were prepared by spray-drying method of a water-slurry of the corresponding metal oxides and titanium dioxide (TiO2, specific surface area (ABET) = 92 m2 g−1). The sample was dried at 100°C for 12 h and calcined in air flow at 350°C for 10 h. The TiO2 materials were commercial products of Millennium Chemicals INC. 2.3 Catalyst characterization The N2 BET surface areas were measured on a Micromeritics (ASAP 2000) analyzer at -196°C. The specific surface areas (ABET) were calculated by the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller equation in the relative pressure range of 0.03 ≤ p/p0 ≤ 0.21. Pore diameter was calculated using the model of Barrett, Joyner, and Halenda from the desorption branch of the isotherm. Temperature programmed reduction with hydrogen (H2-TPR) was carried out on the automatic sample characterization analyzer (AMI-100, Altamira instruments) equipped with a thermal conductivity detector. The temperature was raised from 90 to 700°C in a gas mixture of 5% H2/Ar at heating rate of 10 K min−1. Prior to an experiment the sample was pretreated at 400°C in 20% O2/Ar for 1 h, than cooled to 90°C under flowing argon. Temperature-programmed desorption of ammonia (NH3-TPD) was conducted on a flow-type apparatus equipped with a quartz microreactor. 50 mg of sample were placed in the reactor and pretreated in He-flow at 260°C for 30 min. After cooling down to 90°C the sample was saturated with multiple pulses of pure ammonia. Then the physisorbed ammonia was removed with He-flow (40 ml min-1) before the temperature was elevated to 550°C with 10 K min-1. The evolved gases were on-line analyzed with a mass spectrometer (MS, QME 200, Pfeiffer Vacuum). For detection of NH3 the m/z = 15 (NH) was used. The metal content of the catalyst was determined by atomic absorption spectrometry (AAS; Spectro-AA300, Varian) after their dissolution in an aqueous 65 mass % HNO3 solution (Fluka). Textural and physico-chemical properties are summarized in Table 1 . Among the investigated catalysts, Cu/Al-Si possess the highest specific surface area — 246 m2g−1 and the smallest overage pore diameter — 6.5 nm, for the rest, ABET varies within 140 — 70 m2g−1, PD varies within 9 — 20 nm. It should be noted that due to significant differences in chemical composition and texture of studied catalysts, their physic-chemical properties vary over a rather wide range: total acidity (TA, determined by TPD of ammonia) between 0.16 and 5.6 mmol g−1, hydrogen consumption (H2 cons), determined by temperature programmed reduction with hydrogen between 285 and 3920 μmol g−1. a) determined by RFA analysis; b) the specific surface area (ABET) and the overage pore diameter (PD) c), determined by N2 adsorption/desorption method; d) the total number of acidic sites (TA) determined by TPD of ammonia; e) total hydrogen consumption determined by TPR experiment with hydrogen at the temperature range between 100 and 700°C. 2.4 Catalytic activity experiments Catalytic activity test of liquid-phase cumene oxidation in the presence of NHPI and heterogeneous catalyst was carried out at atmospheric pressure in a manometric homemade closed temperature-controlled gasometric device. The oxidation experiments were conducted using pure oxygen in a glass microreactor (V=5 mL) equipped with magnetic stirring. The catalyst content was varied between 0.01 and 0.04 g mL−1 of the charged cumene (1 mL of RH). Solvent in all runs was acetonitrile, the volume ratio of oxidized mixture: solvent 1:1. Oxidation was carried out under constant pressure of oxygen of 0,101 Mpa and constant reactions temperature of 70°C. 2.5 Analysis of oxidation products According to [31], the problems during gas-chromatography (GC) analysis of cumene oxidations products are associated to the temperature in the injector unit, which usually caused the decomposition of cumen hydroperoxide (CHP). In a series of model measurements it was found that by using of CHP as a reference, at injector temperature between 190 and 200°C CHP can be analyzed as individual compound on 10 m capillary column Rtx®-5 (Restek; Crossbond: 5% diphenyl and 95% dimethyl polysiloxane). The identification and quantitative analysis of products in the cumene oxidates were performed by using this column on GC/MS system (Varian Saturn 2000) and gas chromatograph Chrompack 2001(FID Detector) and carrier gas flow and similar analytic conditions (heating rate 5 K min, injector 190°C, detector 220°; carrier gas – helium, 30 cm s−1. The products has been identified by comparing the observed MS-spectra with the MS spectra of corresponding reference compounds using GS/MS-Varian-Saturn 2000 systems and NIST–MS library. Parallel to GC-method, the cumene oxidates were analyzed using high-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) with a photometric dioden aray (PDA) detector at a wavelength of 220 nm. AC18-HPLC apparatus (JT Baker) equipped with SUPELCOSIL™ LC-18 HPLC- column 5 μm particle size, L × I.D. 25 cm × 4.6 mm; was used. The samples were analyzed using acetonitrile: water as a solvent at a flow rate of 1 mL min−1. The selectivity was calculated as the ratio of product formed and cumene converted. The cumene conversion X(RH) and product selectivity S(Pi) were calculated according to following equations: (1) X ( RH ) = nRHo − nRHt nRHo × 100 % , S ( Pi ) = nPi nRHo − nRHt × 100 % where nRHo and nRHt are the molar amount of the cumene at the beginning and after catalytic reaction and nPi are the molar amount of oxidations products. 3 RESULTS The TMO themselves, after the calcination of corresponding nitrates precursors, possesses a quite low surface area of ca. 1 - 4 m2g−1, which is unsatisfactory for application in heterogeneous catalysis. Therefore, in order to increase the specific surface area of a heterogeneous catalyst, the active TM compounds are usually "loaded“ onto support material. The main features of supported TM oxide catalysts, which are essential for their application in a redox reaction, are electronic structure of TM atom, its coordination environment, the redox behavior and acid-base properties of the solid surface and the specific surface area and the environmental of a support materials. 3.1 Leaching of active metal oxide The leaching of active components from the solid catalyst surface can take place in the presence of polar compounds. The RFA analysis of the spent MnOx, CuOx and VOx catalysts, i.e. after oxidation experiments for 60 min, show that the content of active components was about 2-4 rel.% lower in the comparison to the fresh samples. This indicated that small amount of TMO was washed from the catalyst by contact with the organics phase (ACN-RH). It was found [32] that during oxidation of cyclooctene within 10 h at 40-70°C the leaching of active components of VOx/TiO2 and V-Mo/TiO2 catalysts was less than 5 %. This conclusion is consistent with the results of ICP-OES and RFA analyzes of the spent catalysts VOx/TiO2, VOx-MoOx/TiO2 observed after liquid-phase epoxidation of cycloalkenes with hydroperoxide and hydrogen peroxide in the presence of immobilized Mn and Mo complex [33-35]. Thus, it can be concluded that TM ions are sufficiently strong, bonded to the surface of the support materials. 3.2 Screening for an efficient TMO cocatalyst To estimate the catalytic efficiency of TMOs in the presence of NHPI the oxidation of cumene with molecular oxygen initiated by azo-bis-isobutyronitrile (AIBN) under mild reaction conditions was studied. Carrying the reaction at 70 °С allows primary formed hydroperoxide being preserved from further decomposition. AIBN with its half-life decomposition (τ1/2) of 6 h at 70°C [36] initiates the oxidation for a long period with de-facto constant reaction rates, that substantially facilitates the kinetic analysis of the process. The NHPI produces the phthalimid-N-oxyl radicals (PINO•) which participate in the chain-propagation reactions significantly increasing the reactions rate. To clarify the effect of physico-chemical properties of TMO containing catalysts on the liquid-phase oxidation of cumene the oxygen uptake during initial period of reaction initiated by AIBN-NHPI-system in the presence of constant concentration of catalysts of 10 g L−1 was measured. The oxygen consumption curves obtained at the constant reaction conditions during kinetic experiment with mono and bi TMO containing catalyst are summarized in Figures 1 a and 1b. The calculated initial reaction rates of the oxygen consumption for catalytic oxidation of cumene for the first 800 second reaction time at the constant reaction condition are presented in Fig. 2 3.3 The effect of TMO on reaction rate of oxidation Two groups of supported transition metal oxides were studied as catalysts: one active component V2O5/TiO2, MnOx/TiO2-SiO2, CuOx/Al2O3-SiO2 and binary mixtures of TMO containing e.g. V2O5-MoO3,V2O3-SbO or V2O5-WO3 supported on titanium dioxide. In our preliminary tests it was found that oxidation of pure cumene with molecular oxygen at 70°C and oxygen pressure of 0,101 MPa in the absence of the catalyst or the initiator was not proceeds for a time of more than 2 h. It was also found that in the presence of solely one catalyst (0.04 g mL−1) in cumene oxygen uptake at temperature 70°C occurs with pretty low reaction rates. In all cases the rate was less than 1 × 10−6 M s−1 and only in the case of the most active magnesium oxide it was about 2 × 10−6 M s−1. It allows us to conclude, that under the conditions of our experiments, the reaction rate of cumene C-H bond activation and the free radicals formation are very small. 3.3.1 The catalytic activity of mono TMO active component The results presented in Fig. 1a and Fig. 2 indicate that the mono-oxide catalysts such as Mn/Ti-Si or V/Ti the catalytic systems (e.g. AIBN-NHPI-TMO) exhibit a pronounced catalytic activity and accelerate oxygen uptake when comparing with the run where TMO catalysts are absent. The presence of copper at a sufficiently large content and with a larger specific surface area (ABET) catalyst results in a slower reaction rate. Obtained data of oxidation rates for supported Mn and Cu catalysts are confirmed with the results of previous kinetics study over metal oxide [37]. The catalytic activities of binary TMO-NHPI systems may be compared with those comprised of NHPI and metal salts in oxidation of organic substrates in homogeneous processes. Similar to liquid-phase oxidation of organic substrates in the presence of homogeneous catalytic systems of NHPI with copper, vanadium or manganese salts [38,39], the heterogeneous catalysts Mn/Ti-Si or V/Ti showed higher catalytic activity for cumene oxidation. 3.3.2 Impact of binary mixture of TMO on oxidation rate The results presented in Fig. 2 indicated that the investigated catalysts based on binary mixed-oxide systems such as Mo-V, Sb-V and W-V supported on titania show reduced catalytic activity in the cumene oxidation. Oxidation rates for V-Mo/Ti catalyst are slower comparing to V/Ti catalyst, while for V-Sb/Ti and V-W/Ti catalysts the rate of oxygen uptake experience further decrease. It is worth noting that in the case of VOx containing catalysts the reaction rate become smaller with decreasing vanadium content. The latter indicates of a correlation between the total reaction rate (WO2) and the content of the catalytically active components. Note that in the gas-phase catalytic oxidation of lower alkanes or selective catalytic reduction of NO in the presence of hydrocarbons the oxides of Mo, W or Sb are added to the VOx /TiO2 catalysts in order to suppress a high oxidation activity of VOx species, which often leads to non-selective over-oxidation of hydrocarbons. Moreover, the Mo, Sb, and W oxides in comparison to individual Mn, Cu, and V oxides or supported MnOx, CuOx, and VOx containing catalyst, exhibits lower activity for selective catalytic oxidation and/or different red-ox reaction in the liquid-phase and as well as in the gas-phase reaction of hydrocarbons with molecular oxygen [40]. 3.4 Effect of the amount of solid catalyst We have studied the dependence of the reactions rate of oxidation on the amount of MnOx/TiO2-SiO2 catalyst added in the presence of NHPI (0.02 M) at 70°C. The effect of Mn/Ti-Si catalyst content on the rate of oxygen uptake in the catalytic oxidation of cumene in the presence of NHPI is shown in Fig. 3 . The reaction rate increases with increasing TMO content and reaches a maximum value of 18.6∙10−5 mol L−1s−1 at the catalyst content of about 0.04 g mL−1. The further increasing of the catalyst amount did not cause any significant change of the oxidation rate. While initial growth of the reaction rate results from the synergistic effect of the binary TM-NHPI catalytic system, the following slowdown at the high catalyst concentration can be assigned to the radical termination on the catalyst surface. It was found [41] that despite their great catalytic potential, transition metal oxides are also known by the phenomenon of inhibiting cumene oxidation under certain experimental conditions, particularly, upon increasing their content in the reaction mixture. The phenomenon of the critical amount of the catalyst in processes of liquid-phase oxidation, was also observed by studies [42,43]. This phenomenon observed for heterogeneous liquid phase hydrocarbon oxidation is not well understood and usually is explained by consideration of two distinct sites on the catalyst: active adsorption sites and inactive adsorption sites. In the case of manganese oxide it may be Mn(II)- and Mn(III)-containing centers [44]. Whereas the active sites, Mn(III), forge radicals that initiate/propagate reaction chains, the inactive adsorption sites, Mn(II), on the catalyst surface can participate in chain termination reactions with radicals. Another factor affecting reaction kinetics at the high catalyst concentration might originate from NHPI adsorption on the catalyst surface. PINO• radicals formed from the solute NHPI, increase the reaction rate by contributing to the chain propagation step. Upon decreasing its effective concentration in the reaction volume due to adsorption, catalytic effect of NHPI exerted via propagation step also decreases. In order to test this assumption, we studied the dependence of the oxidation rate on the content of TMO in the same range of changes in its content in the presence of the initiator AIBN. The principal difference in the dependences of the reaction rate on the content of Mn/Ti-Si catalyst at the same concentrations of AIBN then in the case of NHPI were observed. The data presented in Figure 3 show a gradual increase in the oxidation rate over the entire range. Thus, it can be concluded that under these conditions, the chain termination does not occur due to the reaction of the ROO• with the catalyst surface. Therefore, we can conclude that the observed critical concentration of TMO should be related to the participation of PINO• radicals in the chain termination on the catalyst surface. 3.5 Influence of TMO characteristics on their catalytic activity Our data allow us to draw certain conclusions about the effect of the chemical nature of oxides and the properties of its surface on their catalytic properties in the TMO-NHPI system. The above facts suggest that the catalytic properties determine the ability of the catalyst surface to abstract a hydrogen atom from the NHPI molecule. 3.5.1 Impact of the redox characteristics The obtained results on catalytic activities, reaction rates of catalytic oxidation of cumene with the supported TMO were compared with their redox characteristics. Comparison of the data on the catalytic activity of the studied series of catalysts (Fig. 2) and their H2 cons (Table 1) characteristics shows that a general correlation between these values is not observed. Temperature programmed reduction with hydrogen characterizes the oxido-reduction properties of supported catalysts. It is general accepted [45] that the area of hydrogen consumption profiles observed during H2-TPR experiment, have a direct correlation with amount of active oxygen species and corresponds to their oxidation activity in redox system. The reduction behavior of TMO could potentially affect the activity of the catalysts considering the liquid-phase oxidation [46,47]. The H2 cons value characterizes the ability of TMO to oxidize the hydrogen molecule by their oxygen atoms at the temperature up to 400 C. In our case, at a significantly lower temperature, the proceeding of such a reaction can be problematic. There may be a more likely reaction of abstraction of the H-atom by the O-atom of TMO [48,49], which explains the lack of correlation between the activity of the catalyst. 3.5.2 Impact of surface acidity of the catalysts The comparison of the total acid density (TA) of TMO containing catalyst presented in Table 1 and reactions rate of oxidation summarized in Figure 4 and Table 2 indicated that the surface acidity is essential for the activity of the catalyst. Thus, Mn/Ti-Si and V/Ti catalysts with the highest TA of 5.6 and 4.5 exhibit the highest catalytic activity respectively, while catalysts V-Mo/Ti, V-Sb/Ti, VWTi with TA lower than 0.53 are less active for acceleration of oxygen uptake in the liquid-phase oxidation of cumene. Obviously that effect of the surface acidity in the liquid-phase reaction in the presence of heterogeneous catalysts could be explained by competitive interaction (adsorption/desorption) of polar CHP, of a less polar cumene and of the solved oxygen with the surface of the mixed-oxides. Solids materials containing TM behave as a Brønsted and/or Lewis acid sites. Acceleration by acids of aerobic oxidation of C-H bonds has been studied in many studies [50-55]. Lewis acids can efficiently promote various oxidation reactions [56]. In the homogeneous oxidation with HVO3 and KMnO4 the reaction rate increases in the acidic medium. It is explained by an increase in the concentration of active charged oxides VO2 + и MnO3 +, which abstract the H-atom from C–H or O–H bonds with the formation of radicals: O-centered PINO• in the oxidation of NHPI [57] or C-centered radicals in the oxidation of hydrocarbons [58]. Thus, we can assume that the active lattice oxygen of TMO acts as a LAs. The LAs could react directly with adsorbed hydrocarbon molecules with activation of C-H bond of cumene to form a cumyl radical as a intermediate species. In addition, the LAs are able also to abstract H-atom from the -NOH group of NHPI. Formed PINO• radicals further initiate and participate in the radical-chain oxidation reaction of cumene. 3.6 Reaction products To understand the mechanism of catalysis, it is important to know the set of formed major and minor products. the most active. For this purpose, the binary systems containing of 40 g L−1 MnOx/TiO2-SiO2 (the most active TMO) and 0.02 M of NHPI was used. The analysis of reaction mixture in which cumene had been oxidized (38.2 % convertion) at 70 °C and oxygen pressures of 0.1010 MPa by high performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) revealed that the cumene hydroperoxide was the major oxidations product. (69.7 mol.%). Other products such as 2-phenyl-propan-2-ol (2.5 mol.%), acetophenone (21.3 mol.%) and a small amount of α-methyl-styrene (1.2 mol.%), alcohols isomers, oxidation products of oxidative attack on the primary H-C bond [59] of the cumene. (5.10 mol. %) were detected by HPLC analysis. Additionally, in the case of poor resolution of the retention time for individual compound by HPLC the accurate quantitative analysis was carried out by gas-chromatography. The di-cumylperoxide (0.10 mol.%), isomers of cumen-hydroperoxide and isomers of PINO-Cum (0.25 mol.%) compounds were identified using the NIST-МS library from MS-VARIAN-SATURN apparatus. To clarify whether α-methyl-styrene is formed via decomposition of hydroperoxide during GC analysis of the oxidation products or directly in the catalytic oxidation process, the 1 % solution of CHP (purity about of 94 %, iodometry) in chloroform was tested in our GC-analysis conditions. Only two peaks of acetophenone and 2-phenylpropan-2-ol were detected. The absence of α-methyl-styrene in this case suggests that this aryl-alkene is an oxidation product formed in small amount, i.e. less than 1.4 %. Obviously that di-cumyl peroxide (CumOOCum), Cum-NHPI and α-methylstyrene were formed in the reactions of initiation or termination of chains, nonterminating reactions between different free radicals e.g. Cum•, CumOO• and PINO•, respectively. Thus, it can be concluded that all the products obtained in the presence of Mn/Ti-Si+NHPI catalytic system are typical for radical chain liquid phase oxidation of cumene [59]. 3.7 The synergism in oxidation with NHPI-Mn/Ti-Si or V/Ti systems. The kinetics of cumene oxidation in the presence of Mn/Ti-Si and V/Ti, as the most active catalysts, was studied in more detail. In order to obtain a deep information about the role of the each components in the catalytic system, the detailed kinetic studies of oxidation of cumene with different contents of AIBN, NHPI and the TMO MnOx/TiO2•SiO2 and VOx/TiO2 supported oxides were performed. The dependences of the oxidation rate on the catalytic system composition in the reaction mixture are summarized in Table 2. It can be seen, that individual catalysts (i.e. without NHPI, AIBN) Mn/Ti-Si and V/Ti catalysts practically do not affect the cumene oxidation (WO2 less as 0.2•10–5 M s−1). On the other hand, the addition of 0.02 M NHPI to the reaction mixture (run 6 and 7) leads to an significant increase of the reaction rate by a factor of 80 (W6 /W1 ). The V/Ti catalyst, when NHPI is present, exhibits a catalytic effect, but lower than Mn/Ti-Si. These effects could be explained by different loading of transition metal oxide, the content of Mn in Mn /Ti-Si and also their surface area are higher as of V/TiO2. The comparison of oxidation rates of cumene catalyzed by Mn/Ti-Si and V/Ti in the presence of NHPI shows that by catalyst content of 0.04 g mL−1 the Mn/Ti-Si sample affects about two time high activity as V/Ti (comp. runs 6 and 7). It is also interesting to note that in the presence of [AIBN] = 0,02 M, [NHPI] = 0,02 M the total catalyst content was about four times lower (0,01 g mL−1). Thus, V/Ti catalyst exhibits a catalytic effect only slightly lower 11.1•105 M s−1 than that of Mn/Ti-Si 11.5•105 M s−1 (runs 8 and 9 in Table 2). Obviously in the presence of the radical initiator (AIBN) the rate of catalyzed by NHPI+AIBN (run 5) oxidation reaction in chain propagation stage becomes dominant and the proportion of initiation by reactions of the catalyst Mn/Ti-Si or V/Ti with the NHPI will be significantly less. It is very important to note that under used reaction conditions, the reaction rate of oxidation in the presence of TMO+NHPI system is significantly higher than those in the processes catalyzed only by TMO or NHPI. This fact demonstrates the synergistic effect between the NHPI and TMO as cocatalyst. The synergistic factor (Fs) for binary catalytic system was quantified in our studies by the following eqn. 2: (2) F S = W TMO + NHPI / ( W NHPI + W TMO ) where, W TMO (runs 1 or 2 in Table 2), W NHPI(run 4), W TMO+NHPI(runs 6 or 7) are the reaction rate of the oxygen uptake when catalyzed by TMO or NHPI taken alone and their mixture TMO+NHPI, respectively. Using eq.2 and data in Table 2, F was calculated to be 4.8 for MnO+NHPI, which indicates there is a rather strong synergistic effect between these two catalysts. For the system VO+NHPI the F s factor is 2.1. When an initiator AIBN is present in the system and the TMO content is 10 g L−l, the value of F s for both systems is the same 2.9. 4 Discussion 4.1 Molecular catalysis of oxidation by TMO-NHPI system The main feature of the action of TMO in the liquid-phase oxidation under mild reaction conditions is synergism in the catalytic system of TMO + NHPI. Transition metal oxides represent the active phases for selective heterogeneous oxidation catalysis including liquid-phase aerobic oxidation at higher temperatures. Under conditions of our experiments, the addition of a catalyst to cumene leads to very low rates of its oxidation. In the presence of AIBN as the radical initiator the acceleration effect of Mn/Ti-Si is quite small and the reaction rate almost linear slowly increases with increasing of catalyst content in the reaction mixture. Analysis of the reaction products by HPLC method show that the cumen hydroperoxide (CHP) is the major reaction product formed with selectivity of about 72 %. Additionally must be noted that oxidation of cumene does not occur under the conditions of our experiment in the absence of AIBN or NHPI. In the system we use, cumene hydroperoxide is formed in the chain propagation reactions between Ph(CH3)2COO• and cumene or NHPI respectively. The homogeneous liquid-phase aerobic oxidation of hydrocarbons proceeds via the well-established autoxidation mechanism. Since it is radical chain reaction at temperatures up to 90-100 C (70 С, in our case) the addition of the so-called chains starter is necessary to initiate the process. In the presence of an initiator, it proceeds according to the scheme of unbranched chain reaction. If catalysts that decompose hydroperoxides with the formation of free radicals are present, the phenomenon of autocatalysis should be observed. The obtained experimental results and literature data allow us to assume the free radical mechanism for oxidation of cumene in the presence of TMO-NHPI systems. Thus, in the presence of Mn/Ti-Si catalyst the NHPI is able to produce PINO• radical due to abstraction of H-atom from NHPI molecule by surface Mn oxide species. The PINO• radical further reacts with the cumene molecule by abstraction of H-atom producing cumyl radical and initiating chain propagation reactions.The above results indicate that the NHPI-TMO catalysis is more complex: a heterogeneous chain initiation by reaction TMO with NHPI on the catalyst surface with formation of PINO• radical and homogeneous catalysis of chain propagation by PINO• in the liquid phase (Eq. 3 - 9). In the case when formation of side and/or minor reactions products are neglected the reaction of molecular oxygen with a cumene catalyzed with NHPI + TMO catalyst mixture could be represented by reactions (3-11). Initiation on surface (3) TM O S + O 2 + PhM e 2 CH → PhM e 2 C · (4) TM O S + O 2 + NHPI → PIN O · Initiation in liquid phase (5) NHPI + O 2 → PIN O · + HO O · Chain propagation in liquid phase (6) PhM e 2 C · + O 2 → PhM e 2 CO O · (7) PhM e 2 CO O · + PhM e 2 CH → PhM e 2 COOH + PhM e 2 C · (8) PhM e 2 CO O · + NHPI → PhM e 2 COOH + PIN O · (9) PIN O · + PhM e 2 CH → PhM e 2 C · + NHPI Chain termination in liquid phase (10) PhM e 2 CO O · → non radical products Non radical products formation on the solid surface (11) TM O S + PhM e 2 CO O · → non radical products The main reactions that make NHPI a powerful catalyst for the chain initiation and propagation reaction, which, in particular, leads to a significant increase in the selectivity to hydroperoxides are reactions (5) and (8). In addition, the increase in the oxidation rate is also facilitated by the fact that NHPI can take part in the initiation stage according to the reactions on TMO surface (4). It is important that the formed PINO• do not react with ROO• radicals in the chain termination stage [60], that also contributes to an increase in the rate of oxidation and the selectivity of this process. 4.2 Selectivity in TMO+NHPI catalyzed oxidation The formation of CHP as a major product is consistent with previous results [37], where the cumene oxidation in the presence of Ni, Cu and Mn oxides was studied. This can be compared with the results Ishii's group described the preparation of hydroperoxides with 75% yield, using 10 mol% NHPI as the catalyst at 75°C in acetonitrile as the solvent [50]. It is important to consider the ratio of dimethyl-phenyl-carbinol / acetophenone formed during oxidation. These oxidation products can be formed in the following reactions (12) 2 PhM e 2 CO O · → 2 PhM e 2 C O · + O 2 (13) Ph ( C H 3 ) 2 C O · → Ph ( C H 3 ) C = O + · C H 3 (14) PhM e 2 C O · + PhM e 2 CH → PhM e 2 COH + PhM e 2 C · (15) PhM e 2 C O · + NHPI → PhM e 2 COH + PIN O · Due to the predominance of reactions (14) and (15), the formation of dimethyl-phenyl-carbinol will be preferred. However, it is known [15] that when the oxidation of cumene is carried in the presence of NHPI, cobalt acetylacetonate and acetic acid the reaction yields about 54% of acetophenone, 10% of dimethyl-phenyl-carbinol and 17% of phenol with 31% cumene conversion was observed. Thus, if the TM ions are involved in catalysis, the ratio between acetophenone and dimethyl-phenyl-carbinol will be reversed. Therefore, it is logical to assume that, in our case, the formation of these oxidation products is catalyzed by the ionic centers of the surface. The selectivities of di-cumyl peroxide, α-methylstyrene formation are sufficiently lower. Thus, it can be assumed that these two side products are formed in the reactions of initiation or termination of chains namely by non-terminating reactions between two radicals [61,62] (Eq. 16). (16) Ph ( C H 3 ) 2 CO O · + Ph ( C H 3 ) 2 C · → Ph ( C H 3 ) 2 COOC ( C H 3 ) 2 Ph → Ph ( C H 3 ) C = CH Minor occurrence of α-methyl-styrene, is in agreement with previous reports [63-65], which explained their formation by rearrangement reactions (17-19): (17) PhM e 2 C O · + PhM e 2 C · → PhM e 2 COH + PhMeC = C H 2 (18) PhM e 2 C O · + PhM e 2 COOH → PhM e 2 COH + PhMeOOHC − H 2 C · (19) PhMeOOHC − H 2 C · → · OOH + PhMeC = C H 2 The main requirement to production of hydroperoxides by liquid-phase oxidation of hydrocarbons is to avoid over-oxidation and/or decomposition of alkyl hydroperoxides. The use of NHPI-TMO catalytic system, provided with proper solvent and initiator, allows oxidation process being performed at low temperatures. The latter favors improving selectivity towards formation of the target hydroperoxide. Therefore, the important results were obtained in our study. In comparison, CHP synthesis using NHPI as a catalyst with nearly 94-99% selectivity was reported in [13,66]. Also, highly efficient to CHP formation with selectivity of about 96-98%, was reported cumene oxidation catalysed by the ternary catalytic system of NHPI-Fe(acac)3-1,10-phenanthroline [67]. 4.3 On the initiation of oxidation catalyzed with TMO-NHPI system In homogeneous catalysis TM salts participate in the initiation of chain initiation by reaction with hydroperoxide, activate the oxygen and/or the substrate molecules [68]. Under the conditions of heterogeneous catalytic liquid-phase oxidation, the catalyst surface could be involved in the numerous reactions steps. The adsorption of the cumene and CHP on the surface of MoOx/Al2O3 and CoOx/Al2O3 catalysts was studied by IR-spectroscopy [69,70]. It was proposed that the Brønsted acid sites may assist the surface adsorption of cumene and enhancing the catalyst's activity towards formation of various intermediates. Our data allow us to suggest the participation of TMOs in the initiation stage. The active centers of TMO can chemisorb the molecular oxygen and a numerous oxygen species could be formed on the surface of oxide catalysts: the terminal M=O and bridging M–O–M species so called lattice oxygen; two anion radicals, molecular O2 – and atomic O– [71]. Chemisorbed oxygen and oxygen species on the surface can play an important role in the behavior of these catalysts in all stages of oxidation reactions. In the initiation stage it is possible for free radicals to be produced by the reaction of H-atom abstraction [72] in the following ways: (20) 2 * + O 2 ( gas ) → 2 * O (21) * O + PhM e 2 CH → * OH + PhM e 2 C · (22) s M = O + PhM e 2 CH → s M − OH + PhM e 2 C · where: s indicates a part of the catalyst surface and ∗ — a surface active site respectively. Since the oxidation rate in the presence of only TMO is less than 2 10−6 M s−1, the contribution of these reactions in the case of catalysis by the TMO-NHPI system will be small. It can be assumed that the contribution to the initiation of reactions of the decomposition of hydroperoxide on the catalyst surface will also be low. According to [43] the interactions of ROOH with the surface of TMO containing catalysts may play a significant role in initiation steps: (23) * + PhMe 2 COOH ⇄ [ * − − − PhMe 2 COOH ] → * + PhMe 2 CO Â· + HO Â· An important proof of the small contribution of the reaction (23) to initiation is the fact that we did not observe autocatalysis in any of the kinetic experiments in which catalysis with TMT was studied. The obtained experimental results allow us to assume that the participation of NHPI in the initiation stage is crucial. Taking into account the literature data [49, 73] on the cumene oxidation, the most likely reaction of radical formation can be presented as follows: (24) s Mn = O + NHPI → s Mn − OH + PIN O · (25) s Mn − OH + O 2 → s Mn = O + HO O · (26) s M n n + + O 2 → s M n n + 1 − O O · + NHPI → s M n n + 1 − OOH + PIN O · Obviously, NHPI molecules in the presence of Mn active species (i.e. Mn=O of Mn/Ti-Si catalyst) are able to produce PINO• radicals due to H-atom abstraction by surface manganese (IV) oxide species. The PINO• radicals reacts further with the cumene molecule to abstract the H-atom and to form a cumyl radicals PhMe2C• starting chain propagation reactions in liquid-phase (6–9). In addition, the possibility of the activation of the O-H bond in NHPI adsorbed on the catalyst surface and the reaction of such a complex with an oxygen molecule can be considered (27) TMO + NHPI ⇄ TMO − NHPI (28) TMO − NHPI + O 2 → TMO + PIN O · + HO O · 4.4 Perspective of TMO-NHPI system in low temperature radical processes The interaction of NHPI, molecular oxygen, cumene hydroperoxide and cumene with the surface of metal oxide in the liquid-phase is only partly understood on the molecular level and may depend both on the surface acid-base and also on the redox property of the heterogeneous catalysts. Nevertheless, the results obtained for liquid-phase oxidation of cumene in presence of NHPI+Mn catalytic system demonstrate the perspective for their application for synthesis of CHP at reaction temperature below 80°C. It is especially worth noting that the binary NHPI-TMO system based on heterogeneous MnOx or VOx catalysts are perspective for the use as the low temperature initiators in different radical processes which occur with the participation of C-centered free radicals.. 5 Conclusion A series of heterogeneous catalysts containing Mn, V and Cu oxides supported on TiO2, Al2O3 and TiO2-SiO2 has been prepared, characterized and investigated in liquid-phase oxidation of cumene as co-catalyst in the presence of NHPI. The Mn/Ti-Si and V/Ti catalysts with highest surface acidity were found to be most active cocatalysts for the oxidation of cumene. A synergistic effect was found for the binary systems Mn/Ti-Si +NHPI and V/Ti+NHPI in the liquid phase catalytic oxidation of tetr-C-H bond of cumene. The observed effects are explained as follows. NHPI reacts with TMO or molecular oxygen gives PINO• radicals, which take part in the initiation and propagation of the chain, and being not involving in chain termination steps in liquid-phase significantly increase the overall rate of the radical chain oxidation process. A kinetic scheme that takes into account the main features of this process, the participation of TMO in the initiation reactions and NHPI in the initiation and chain propagation reactions is proposed. Accordingly, Mn and V oxide based catalysts combined with NHPI could be a promising catalytic system and alternatives to conventional non-catalytic process of aerobic cumene oxidation for selective preparation of cumene hydroperoxide. The selection of the supported transition metal oxides, characteristics of which can be finely tuned both by the nature of the TM and by the support properties, by combination with NHPI seems help to find the key factors for the development of an improved and/or new catalytic system for the effective low temperature aerobic oxidation reaction of hydrocarbons. Therefore, this study provides a general strategy to design of a binary or hybrid catalytic system which allows creating and operating selective, aerobic oxidation processes not only of cumene but also various hydrocarbons at low temperature and/or mild reaction conditions Author Contributions W.Ya.Suprun managed GC/GC-MS, H2-TPD and NH3-TPD analysis and catalysts. coredata.dc:description: The heterogeneous catalysts based on single active component such as V2O5, MnOx and CuOx and bi-components V2O5-MoO3 V2O5-WO3 and V2O5-SbOx supported onto TiO2, TiO2-SiO2 and Al2O3-SiO2 was prepared and characterized. The aerobic liquid-phase oxidation of cumene (RH) in the presence of binary catalytic system containing N-hydroxyphthalimide (NHPI) and supported V, Mn and Cu oxides has been studied. It was observed that catalytic activities of the mono metallic systems decreases in order V2O5 ≈ MnOx > CuOx, bi-metallic catalysts showed no catalytic activities. The effect of catalytic system composition comprising MnOx or VOx and NHPI, AIBN on the oxidation rate was studied. The major oxidations product was cumene hydroperoxide, whereas dimethyl phenyl carbinol and acetophenone were found as minor ones. The reactions scheme that summarizes the oxidation chemistry identifying the related role of heterogeneous initiation and homogeneous propagation and termination steps for oxidation of cumene via free-radical mechanism are presented.
coredata.dc:title: Supported transition metals oxides and N-hydroxyphthalimide as binary catalytic systems for the liquid-phase oxidation of cumene
